natural problem: In how many ways can one write the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 in a row so that given any number in the row, all of its divisors (not including itself) appear to its left?
natural solution: We begin by finding all possible ways to arrange the 1, 2, 3, and 6. There are only two orders which satisfy the conditions of the problem, namely $(1, 2, 3, 6)$ and $(1, 3, 2, 6)$.

We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.

Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p \<in> set (f p)"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> distinct (f p)"
and h2 : "\<forall> p d. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<and> d dvd p \<and> d < p \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. i < j \<and> f p ! i = d \<and> f p ! j = p)"
shows  "card {f p | p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6} = 25"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can one write the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 in a row so that given any number in the row, all of its divisors (not including itself) appear to its left? The final Answer is 25
 ### Proof
 We begin by finding all possible ways to arrange the 1, 2, 3, and 6. There are only two orders which satisfy the conditions of the problem, namely $(1, 2, 3, 6)$ and $(1, 3, 2, 6)$.
 We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.
 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p \<in> set (f p)"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> distinct (f p)"
and h2 : "\<forall> p d. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6 \<and> d dvd p \<and> d < p \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. i < j \<and> f p ! i = d \<and> f p ! j = p)"
shows  "card {f p | p. p > 0 \<and> p \<le> 6} = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
For each positive integer $p \leq 6$, we have a list $f(p)$ such that:

1. All integers in the list are distinct.
2. $p$ is an element of the list.
3. For every divisor $d$ of $p$ with $d < p$, there exist two distinct indices $i$ and $j$ such that $f(p)[i] = d$ and $f(p)[j] = p$.

How many distinct lists can be formed for all $p$ in this range? The final answer is 25.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<le> n. (\<forall> d. d dvd k \<and> d \<noteq> k \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. i < j \<and> ways i = d \<and> ways j = k))"
shows  "card {ways i | i. i \<le> n} = 25"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can one write the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 in a row so that given any number in the row, all of its divisors (not including itself) appear to its left? The final Answer is 25
 ### Proof
 We begin by finding all possible ways to arrange the 1, 2, 3, and 6. There are only two orders which satisfy the conditions of the problem, namely $(1, 2, 3, 6)$ and $(1, 3, 2, 6)$.
 We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.
 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<le> n. (\<forall> d. d dvd k \<and> d \<noteq> k \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. i < j \<and> ways i = d \<and> ways j = k))"
shows  "card {ways i | i. i \<le> n} = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a sequence of numbers, $ways$, with a length of 6, such that for every $k \leq 6$, any divisor $d$ of $k$ different from $k$ can be found as $ways(i)$ and $ways(j)$ with $i < j$. Find the number of distinct values in the sequence $ways$. The final answer is 25.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and count :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "count = card {perms | perms. bij_betw perms {1..n} {1..n} \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> {1..n}. \<forall> d. d dvd x \<and> d \<noteq> x \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. perms i = x \<and> perms j = d \<and> i > j))}"
shows  "count = 25"
a_2.formal solution:

 We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.
 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and count :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "count = card {perms | perms. bij_betw perms {1..n} {1..n} \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> {1..n}. \<forall> d. d dvd x \<and> d \<noteq> x \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i j. perms i = x \<and> perms j = d \<and> i > j))}"
shows  "count = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider the set of permutations of the numbers from 1 to 6, where for each number $x$ in the permutation, if there is a divisor $d$ of $x$ such that $d \neq x$, then $x$ appears after $d$ in the permutation. How many such permutations are there? The final answer is 25.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> row. row_permutation [1..k] row \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> i j. i < j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> i \<in> set row \<and> j \<in> set row \<and> row ! i dvd row ! j \<longrightarrow> row ! i < row ! j))"
shows  "ways 6 = 25"
a_3.formal solution:

 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

fixes n :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> row. row_permutation [1..k] row \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> i j. i < j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> i \<in> set row \<and> j \<in> set row \<and> row ! i dvd row ! j \<longrightarrow> row ! i < row ! j))"
shows  "ways 6 = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 6 distinct positive integers in which all elements are less than or equal to 6. How many such sequences exist where any two elements that are both in the sequence and are in ascending order such that one divides the other must also satisfy the property that the smaller element comes before the larger element in the sequence? The final answer is 25.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> l. set l = {1..n} \<longrightarrow> length l = n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> j \<in> {1..n}. f i = l!j \<and> (\<forall> k < j. l!k \<noteq> d))))"
shows  "card {l. set l = {1..n} \<and> length l = n \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> j \<in> {1..n}. f i = l!j \<and> (\<forall> k < j. l!k \<noteq> d))))} = 25"

 *)

fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"

shows  "card {l. set l = {1..n} \<and> length l = n \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> j \<in> {1..n}. f i = l!j \<and> (\<forall> k < j. l!k \<noteq> d))))} = 25"
 proof-

a_4.informal problem: In how many ways can you arrange the numbers 1 to 6 in a list such that for each number $i$ in the list, if $d$ is a divisor of $i$ and $d \neq i$, then $d$ appears somewhere earlier in the list? The final answer is 25.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and A :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "valid_row A"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. i \<in> set A"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k < index A i \<and> A ! k = d))"
shows  "card {A. valid_row A \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. i \<in> set A) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k < index A i \<and> A ! k = d))} = 25"
a_5.formal solution:

 We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.
 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and A :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "valid_row A"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. i \<in> set A"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k < index A i \<and> A ! k = d))"
shows  "card {A. valid_row A \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. i \<in> set A) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (\<forall> d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k < index A i \<and> A ! k = d))} = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider a list A of 6 distinct natural numbers, where each number from 1 to 6 is present in the list. A list is valid if for every number i in the list, all its divisors (except itself) appear earlier in the list. How many valid lists can be constructed with these conditions? The final answer is 25.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> set (f i) \<and> (\<forall>d. d dvd i \<and> d \<noteq> i \<longrightarrow> d \<in> set (f i))"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> f i \<noteq> f j"
shows  "card {f i | i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}} = 25"
a_7.formal solution:

fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"

and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> f i \<noteq> f j"
shows  "card {f i | i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}} = 25"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Consider a function $f$ that maps a natural number $i$ to a list of natural numbers. This function has the following properties:

1. $i$ is always an element of the list $f(i)$, and for every divisor $d$ of $i$ (excluding $i$ itself), $d$ is also in the list $f(i)$.
2. For any two distinct natural numbers $i$ and $j$, the lists $f(i)$ and $f(j)$ are different.

Find the number of unique elements in the set of lists generated by applying the function $f$ to the numbers from 1 to 6. The final answer is 25.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and count_permutations :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i > 0 \<and> i \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> p. p permutes {1..n} \<and> (\<forall> j \<le> i. p j dvd p (j+1) \<and> p j \<noteq> p (j+1))) \<longrightarrow> count_permutations i = card {p. p permutes {1..n} \<and> (\<forall> j \<le> i. p j dvd p (j+1) \<and> p j \<noteq> p (j+1))}"
shows  "count_permutations n = 25"
a_8.formal solution:

 We now insert the 4 into the lineup, keeping in mind that it must appear to the right of the 1 and 2. There are three possible positions in the first case and two spots in the second case, bringing the total number of orderings to five.
 Finally, when placing the 5 into any one of these orderings we need only ensure that it appears to the right of the 1, so there are five possibilities for each of our five orderings, making $\boxed{25}$ orderings in all.
 *)

shows  "count_permutations n = 25"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a set of 6 distinct elements numbered from 1 to 6. Find the total number of permutations of these elements such that for each $i$ from 1 to 6, the element at position $i$ divides the element at position $i+1$ and the two elements are not equal. The final answer is 25.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes perm :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "set perm = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n i. i < length perm \<and> perm ! i = n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>d. d dvd n \<and> d \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>j. j < i \<and> perm ! j = d))"
shows  "card {p. p permutes {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> (\<forall>n i. i < length p \<and> p ! i = n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>d. d dvd n \<and> d \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>j. j < i \<and> p ! j = d)))} = 25"

fixes perm :: "nat list"

shows  "card {p. p permutes {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> (\<forall>n i. i < length p \<and> p ! i = n \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>d. d dvd n \<and> d \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>j. j < i \<and> p ! j = d)))} = 25"

a_9.informal problem: Consider a permutation of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. A permutation is valid if for every index i and number n such that the element at index i is n, all divisors d of n (excluding n itself) have an index j less than i where the element at index j is d. How many valid permutations are there? The final answer is 25.
